title: Lesson 53 – More, Most, Very; Mas, Pinaka, Sobra, Gustong-gusto

contents.markdown: This lesson will cover the Tagalog versions of the comparative (“more” or “-er” in English), superlative (“most” or “-est” in English) and intensifier (“very” in English).
<u>More: Mas</u>
_Mas_ is an adverb that roughly means “more” or “-er”. We will use it before adjectives or pseudo verbs:

item.tagalog: Mas gusto ko ang mabilis na sasakyan.
item.english: I like the fast car more.

contents.markdown: _Lalo_(adv) and _higit_(adv) can also be used to express “more”:

item.english: Her child is getting even more big.

contents.markdown: But they have special usages and are less common than _mas_, so we will not use them any further. You can make “more than” statements using kaysa:
Mas + phrase1 + kaysa + phrase2. (Tag.) = Phrase1 is more than phrase2. (Eng.)
\*\*Notes: Phrase1 starts with an adjective or pseudo verb. Phrase2 takes _sa_ form.\*\*

item.tagalog: Mas mabilis si David kaysa kay Joe.
Mas masaya na babae si Analyn kaysa kay Jasmine.
item.english: Analyn is a happier woman than Jasmine.

item.tagalog: Mas gusto kong magbisikleta kaysa sa magmaneho.
item.english: I like to bicycle more than to drive.

contents.markdown: These comparisons can also be buried within a sentence:

item.tagalog: Kukunin ni David ang mga mangga nang mas mabilis kaysa kay Joe.
item.english: David will get the mangoes faster than Joe.

contents.markdown: <u>Most: Pinaka-</u>
The prefix _pinaka_- is added to adjectives to create the meaning of “most” or “-est”.

item.tagalog: Gusto ko ang pinakamura na bisikleta.

contents.markdown: <u>Very Adjective: Sobra</u>

As a noun, _sobra_ means “excess”. As an adjective, it means “excessive” or “so”. As an adverb it means “excessively”, and colloquially, although it is not a direct translation, it is the most common way to express “very”.
To apply this to a name, it must take _ng_ form:
Sobrang + **adj root** + linker + noun + name. = Name is a very adj noun.
\*\*Note: Name takes _ng_ form.\*\*

item.english: Jessica is a very beautiful woman.

contents.markdown: Notice that the adjective root is the host, so if we turn the name into a pp:

item.english: She is a very beautiful woman.

contents.markdown: _Sobra_ can be used as an adverb of manner with a verb:
But we will not use it that way, since a different adverb is normally used.
The prefix _napaka_- can be added to roots to create adjectives with the direct translation of “very”.

item.english: Jessica is a very beautiful woman. (Note that, like with sobra, Jessica takes ng form.)

contents.markdown: But these are less common, and to be consistent, we will only use sobra for “very” adjective.
<u>Very Pseudo Verb: Gustong-gusto</u>
_Sobra_ can be used for pseudo verbs too, but the most common way to express “very” for pseudo verbs is to repeat them:
pv + linker + pv (Tag.) = very pv (Eng.)
Note: If the linker ends in _g_, join the pseudo verbs with a dash.

item.english: I like the Philippines very much.
We (excl.) are very able to eat lechon.

item.tagalog: Bawal na bawal magmaneho sa eskwelahan.
item.english: It is very much prohibited to drive in school.

contents.markdown: It is also possible to do this with adjectives:

item.english: Jessica is a very beautiful woman. (Note that, like with sobra, Jessica takes ng form.)

item.tagalog: Lumaki siya nang mabilis na mabilis.

contents.markdown: But this is a bit less common than _sobra_, so we will not use it for adjectives.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Oo, mas nakakatuwa siya, pero hindi siya ganun kabilis.
exampleSentences.english: Yes, she is more entertaining, but she is not that fast.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Mas gusto kong manood ng TV kaysa sa maging pangulo.
exampleSentences.english: I want to watch TV more than to be president.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Pareho ba ang sampung pinakanakakainis na kasama ni Jasmine?
exampleSentences.english: Are Jasmine's ten most annoying companions the same?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Kasing bilis ng sobrang pagod na manok ang bata.
exampleSentences.english: The kid is as fast as the very tired chicken.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Gustong-gusto niya ang nangyayari dahil sa ulan.
exampleSentences.english: She very much likes what is happening due to the rain.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Parang mas nakatutok sila nung namasyal sila sa labas.
exampleSentences.english: It seems they were more focused when they went for a walk outside.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Mas nakakatakot si Luis kaysa kina Analyn at Diego.
exampleSentences.english: Luis is scarier than Analyn and Diego.
My favorite work is like this.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Namimili lang si Mark ng sobrang murang sapatos.
exampleSentences.english: Mark is only shopping for very cheap shoes.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Kailangang-kailangan mong bumili ng tsokolate para sa asawa ko!
exampleSentences.english: You really need to buy chocolate for my wife!
